messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Rigid continuation paths II. Structured polynomial systems

Paper Abstract: Abstract. This work studies the average complexity of solving structured polynomial systems that are characterized by a low evaluation cost, as opposed to the dense random model previously used. Firstly, we design a continuation algorithm that computes, with high probability, an approximate zero of a polynomial system given only as black-box evaluation program. Secondly, we introduce a universal model of random polynomial systems with prescribed evaluation complexity LùêøL. Combining both, we show that we can compute an approximate zero of a random structured polynomial system with nùëõn equations of degree at most Œ¥ùõø\delta in nùëõn variables with only poly‚Å°(n,Œ¥)‚ÄãLpolyùëõùõøùêø\operatorname{poly}(n,\delta)L operations with high probability. This exceeds the expectations implicit in Smale‚Äôs 17th problem.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Condition Length and Complexity for the Solution of Polynomial Systems",
        "The Complexity of Partial Derivatives",
        "A Continuation Method to Solve Polynomial Systems and Its Complexity",
        "Certified Numerical Homotopy Tracking",
        "Robust Certified Numerical Homotopy Tracking",
        "On Smale‚Äôs 17th Problem: A Probabilistic Positive Solution",
        "Smale‚Äôs 17th Problem: Average Polynomial Time to Compute Affine and Projective Solutions",
        "Fast Linear Homotopy to Find Approximate Zeros of Polynomial Systems",
        "Complexity of Bezout‚Äôs Theorem. VII. Distance Estimates in the Condition Metric",
        "Concentration Inequalities: A Nonasymptotic Theory of Independence",
        "Completeness and Reduction in Algebraic Complexity Theory, Algorithms and Computation in Mathematics",
        "Condition of Intersecting a Projective Variety with a Varying Linear Subspace",
        "On a Problem Posed by Steve Smale",
        "Condition: The Geometry of Numerical Algorithms, Grundlehren Der Mathematischen Wissenschaften 349",
        "Multihomogeneous Newton Methods",
        "On Condition Numbers and the Distance to the Nearest Ill-Posed Problem",
        "Curvature Measures",
        "A Gr√∂bner Free Alternative for Polynomial System Solving",
        "Certified Predictor‚ÄìCorrector Tracking for Newton Homotopies",
        "Algorithm 921: alphaCertified: Certifying Solutions to Polynomial Systems",
        "The Kinematic Formula in Riemannian Homogeneous Spaces",
        "A Global Lojasiewicz Inequality for Algebraic Varieties",
        "A Deterministic Algorithm to Compute Approximate Roots of Polynomial Systems in Polynomial Average Time",
        "Rigid Continuation Paths I. Quasilinear Average Complexity for Solving Polynomial Systems",
        "A Single Exponential Bound on the Complexity of Computing Gr√∂bner Bases of Zero Dimensional Ideals",
        "Characterizing Valiant‚Äôs Algebraic Complexity Classes",
        "Lower Bounds for Non-Commutative Computation",
        "Univariate Polynomials: Nearly Optimal Algorithms for Factorization and Rootfinding",
        "Optimal and Nearly Optimal Algorithms for Approximating Polynomial Zeros",
        "On the Worst-Case Arithmetic Complexity of Approximating Zeros of Polynomials",
        "On the Worst-Case Arithmetic Complexity of Approximating Zeros of Systems of Polynomials",
        "Function theory in the unit ball of ‚ÑÇnsuperscript‚ÑÇùëõ\\mathbb{C}^{n}, Grundlehren der Mathematischen Wissenschaften 241",
        "Verified Error Bounds for Multiple Roots of Systems of Nonlinear Equations",
        "Complexity of Bezout‚Äôs Theorem. VI. Geodesics in the Condition (Number) Metric",
        "Complexity of Bezout‚Äôs Theorem. II. Volumes and Probabilities",
        "Complexity of Bezout‚Äôs Theorem. III. Condition Number and Packing",
        "Complexity of B√©zout‚Äôs Theorem. I. Geometric Aspects",
        "Complexity of Bezout‚Äôs Theorem. V. Polynomial Time",
        "Complexity of Bezout‚Äôs Theorem. IV. Probability of Success; Extensions",
        "Newton‚Äôs Method Estimates from Data at One Point",
        "Complexity Theory and Numerical Analysis",
        "Mathematical Problems for the next Century",
        "A Robust Numerical Path Tracking Algorithm for Polynomial Homotopy Continuation",
        "Mixed Precision Path Tracking for Polynomial Homotopy Continuation",
        "Classes of Arithmetic Circuits Capturing the Complexity of Computing the Determinant",
        "Completeness Classes in Algebra",
        "Reducibility by Algebraic Projections"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Rigid continuation paths II. Structured polynomial systems, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
